title: 110_hr1318
content: The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. Title 38, United States Code, is amended to remove certain subsections and requirements for individuals seeking recognition under this section. The Secretary may now require individuals to demonstrate good moral character, competence, and qualifications to assist claimants. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It amends Title 38, United States Code, by removing certain subsections and requirements for individuals seeking recognition. The Secretary can now require individuals to demonstrate good moral character, competence, and qualifications to assist claimants. Additionally, subsection (c) of section 5904 is amended to repeal certain paragraphs. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" removes agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs by amending subsection (c) of section 5904 of Title 38, United States Code. This includes repealing certain paragraphs and modifying the date for commencement of services. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends section 5904 of Title 38, United States Code by removing agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes changes to paragraphs and the date for commencement of services. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends section 5904 of Title 38, United States Code by removing agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It also includes provisions for the Board to review fee agreements and order reductions if fees are deemed excessive or unreasonable. The Act allows for review by the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Additionally, section 5905 is amended to address penalties for violations. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends section 5904 of Title 38, United States Code by removing agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It also includes provisions for the Board to review fee agreements and order reductions if fees are deemed excessive or unreasonable. The Act allows for review by the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Section 5905 is amended to address penalties for violations, including soliciting fees not provided for in the law.
